subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... all.) ... who ... been ... to ... text side ... it. I ... tried to ... Australian ... of the ... list of ... side with ... If you want to see what an
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn wrote:
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, John Cowan <cowan@>
wrote:
> >
> > >(There are also splits, where a lexical set divides into two
> > >different pronunciations, but QS just can't handle those at
all.)
> >
> > True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot. But QS treated
> > phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user
who
> > tried to find a letter for a sound and failed. The problem has
been
> > the reverse: we find too many letters that work. There are two
> > proposals now to solve this:
> > 1. do not use letters for sounds not found in your accent.
> > 2. follow a complex set of rules to simulate Upper Class British
> > English.
> > My bias is towards number 1.
> >
> > >> it is just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is
> > unimportant.
> > >Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.
> >
> > I'm sure you have a basis for this figure even though it so very
> > strongly resembles a complete guess. It would perhaps be better
to
> > show us an Australian and Non-Australian version of the same
text side
> > by side as I have done with US vs RP here:
>
> > http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html
>
> This comparison is in senior QS, right? I have a hard time reading
it. I
> too would like to see concrete examples at this point. I have
tried to
> see what QS might look like if written phonetically for the
Australian
> dialect. (My understanding is that there are not letters for some
of the
> sounds in Australian English; but at least show this in a concrete
> example and try to approxtimate). But I can't find a really good
list of
> words.
>
> The words wouldn't have to be in QS; they could appear side by
side with
> their IPA transcriptions for each word.
>
> This is all I've been able to find so far:
>
> Australian "day" sounds like "die";
> Australian "buy" sounds like "boy".
>

If you want to see what an example of Australian junior quickscript,
you can look chapter 12 of my tutorials:
http://members.optusnet.com.au/~malt99/project_quickscript_website/index.html
where the spellings used follow the pronunciations in the MacQuarie
Dictionary (this dictionary is an Australian dictionary: its was one
of two that students were allowed to use in the Queensland state
primary school system when I was a pupil- the other dictionary was
the Oxford. The MacQuarie is generally considered to be the national
dictionary.) The majority of Australians have the same general
accent, due to the fact that it is a only a couple of hundred years
old, it is very urbanised (basically Australia is just five cities -
I think it has some claim to being the worlds most urbanised
country) where most TV broadcasts and some radio are Australia wide.
The broad drawn-out country Australian accent where people say day
as die is not really representative of the majority.
